h i g h l i g h t s
Effect of nanofluids in solar steam and pure water generation was investigated. The performance of MWCNT, SWCNT, GO and GNP nanomaterials was compared. The sensible heat storage of nanofluids during the light on and off were studied. High quality of distilled water was proved by seawater desalination using nanofluids.

Keywords: Steam generation Carbon nanomaterials Nanofluid Solar simulator Experimental study
a b s t r a c t
In the present study, the performance of water based-nanofluids containing four different types of carbon nanostructures for solar vapor generation has experimentally been investigated. The considered nanofluids are multi-walled carbon nanotube, single-walled carbon nanotube, graphene nanoplate and graphene oxide. Nanofluids with three nanoparticle mass concentrations of 0.001%, 0.002%, and 0.004% were prepared and their evaporation characteristics were investigated for solar radiation intensities in the range of 1.5 and 3.5 Suns. The results indicated that the multi-walled carbon nanotube nanofluid with a mass concentration of 0.004% provides the highest evaporation rate with the maximum total efficiency of 94% at 3.5 Suns. The total efficiencies for nanofluids containing the single-walled carbon nanotube, graphene nanoplate and graphene oxide at similar conditions and that of pure water, respectively, are about 91%, 90%, 81% and, 54%. Furthermore, it is observed that for the mass concentration of 0.004%, the evaporation rate with respect to water increases to about 72%, 63%, 58% and 36%, respectively, for the multi-walled carbon nanotube, the single-walled carbon nanotube, graphene nanoplate and graphene oxide nanofluids. As far as the sensible heat is concerned, graphene oxide shows the most considerable sensible heating efficiency at the mass concentration of 0.004% with the maximum fluid bulk temperature rise of 20.5 C, which is 40% higher than that of water. Finally, it was found that increasing the radiation intensity from 1.5 to 3.5 Suns improves the evaporation rate; however, the sensible heat efficiency is more influenced such that the evaporation efficiency declines. The quality of the produced water from a seawater sample is also examined and it was shown that it is well below the limitations of the drinking water standards.

1. Introduction
In recent years, many studies have been done on fundamentals and applications of nanofluids (Mahian et al., 2019a, 2019b). A

nanofluid can be used as a phase change material (Xu et al., 2019, Sheikholeslami and Mahian 2019), as a liquid fuel (Zhang et al., 2018), a heat carrier in a simple tube (Amani et al., 2017; Sekrani et al., 2018) or a solar thermal device (Subramani et al., 2018; Mahian et al., 2013), and as a working fluid in a cavity with natural convection mode (Minea and El-Maghlany 2017; Sheikholeslami et al., 2017). Recently, the application of nanofluids for solar vapor generation has attracted particular attention due to its direct energy conversion, which reduces energy losses associated with the applications that indirectly benefit from the solar energy. Nanoparticles play a significant role in the enhancement of direct absorption of solar energy (Hjerrild and Taylor, 2017; Neumann et al., 2013).
Previous studies indicated that the bandgap of semiconductors and the resonance plasmonic parameter (or forbidden energy zone) of conductors (metallic substances) are among the most important martial properties for light absorption (Brongersm et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2017a). For example, gold (Neumann et al., 2013; Jin et al., 2016) and silver (Li et al., 2017) nanoparticles when exposed to the solar radiation can generate a dramatic heat via a surface plasmonic effect, increasing their local temperature. Jin et al. (2016), Amjad et al. (2017) and Wang et al. (2017b) studied the performance of Au nanoparticles on solar steam generation. The total efficiency was found to be 81% at solar irradiation of 220 Suns (Jin et al., 2016), 80.3% at 280 Suns (Amjad et al., 2017), and 65% at 10 Suns (Wang et al., 2017b). It should be mentioned that metallic nanomaterials mainly react to a partial range of the solar spectrum, while the performance of a large number of the light-absorbing organic materials decay with aging. Therefore, it is a challenge to find a photothermal converter with high efficiency and stability properties. Evidently, the low efficiency of direct solar energy conversion systems is still one of the main obstacles in their commercialization (Wang et al., 2017c, 2017a).
Carbon nanostructures in the solar-driven steam generation have recently attracted attention due to their appropriate band gap for photothermal solar energy conversion and also the important applications of the low-cost generated steam. Ni et al. (2015) reported steam generation efficiency of 69% at the solar intensity of 10 Suns via carbon black, graphene and graphitized carbon black dispersed in water with the mass concentration of 0.5%. Wang et al. (2016a) investigated the performance of CNT in solar vapor generation. The effects of solar intensity (1, 3, 5, and 10 Suns) and CNT concentration on the solar vapor generation were examined. An evaporation efficiency of 45% was reported for the CNT nanofluid with a volume concentration of 19.04 10 4% exposed to the 10 Suns irradiation. Shi et al. (2017) examined the Fe3O4/CNT nanocomposites and obtained the evaporation efficiency of 60.3% under 10 Suns irradiation. They have also investigated the recovery potential of the Fe3O4/CNT nanoparticles from the nanofluid with the help of a magnetic field, where 98% of the initial nanoparticles mass was recovered.
Liu et al. (2018) fabricated reduced graphene oxide in search for the low band gap nanoparticles. The effects of mass concentration (1.25–10 ppm) and irradiation intensity (1, 3, 5, and 7 Suns) on solar steam generation were studied experimentally. The evaporation efficiency of 60.3% was obtained for a mass concentration of 10 ppm exposed to 10 Suns irradiation. Ghafurian et al. (2018) examined the performance of MWCNT functionalized with carboxyl (ACOOH) and hydroxyl (AOH) groups in solar fresh water production. The nanoparticle mass concentrations of 0.0005%, 0.001%, and 0.002% were tested under 1.2, 2.2, and 3.2 Suns irradiation. The maximum evaporation efficiency of 34.63% was obtained for the modified carbon nanotubes with hydroxyl groups at a light intensity of 3.2 Suns.
Fu et al. (2017) examined the effects of adding Au nanoparticles into GO nanofluids on solar vapor generation. It was shown that the combination of Au/GO nanoparticles with a concentration of 15.6% improves the evaporation efficiency of about 22.3% as compared to the GO nanofluid efficiency. Li et al. (2017) achieved the total efficiency of 72% with Ag/TiO2 (200 ppm) under 10 Suns irradiation.
The above literature survey clearly indicates that the direct solar vapor generation using nanofluids is still an innovative topic with various gaps that should be concealed. Selection of most suitable nanoparticles (considering morphology, mass fraction, and cost) can optimize the performance of such systems. In this regard, the present study aims to compare the potential of various types of carbon-based nanoparticles for efficiency enhancement of solar vapor generation. Different carbon nanoparticles including single-wall carbon nanotube (SWCNT), multi wall carbon nanotube (MWCNT), graphene nanoplate (GNP) and graphene oxide (GO) dispersed in water have been examined for solar vapor generation using a solar simulator. The effects of different parameters such as nanoparticle concentration and light intensity on the fluid temperature (light on and off), evaporation rate, sensible heat capacity have been examined in details. Eventually, the quality of the produced desalinated water from a seawater sample has also been investigated based on the concentrations of the five ions that are naturally present in the seawater known as Na+, Mg2+, K+, Ca2+, B3+.

sections.heading: 2. Nanocarbon structures and nanofluids
sections.text:
Water based-nanofluids containing SWCNT (diameter of 2 nm and length of 5–20 lm), MWCNT (with the diameter of 20– 30 nm and length of 5–10 lm), GNP (diameter of 1–20 lm and thickness less than 40 nm), and GO (diameter of 1–20 lm and thickness of 1–10 nm) were purchased from Vira Carbon Nano Materials Company. Nanofluids were prepared by a one-step method at three mass fractions of 0.001%, 0.002%, 0.004%. In Fig. 1(a–d) the TEM images of the mentioned nanoparticles dispersed in water are presented.
The zeta potential of samples was measured by a Zeta Compact instrument as a measure for the nanofluid dispersion stability. In general, when the absolute zeta potential of a nanofluid is greater
than 30 mV, the nanofluid can be considered as stable (Wang et al., 2017a; Sharafeldina et al., 2017). The results of stability analysis reveal that the zeta potential values for GNP, SWCNT, MWCNT and GO at pH of 6, respectively, are 30.79, 29.91, 31.42 and 32.95 mV indicating the acceptable stability for all prepared samples (Fig. 1(e)). Besides, visual inspections during the evaporation tests confirmed the appropriate stability of all the samples. Fig. 1 (f) also exhibits the appearance of the prepared nanofluids containing MWCNT, SWCNT, GNP, and GO nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 3. Solar simulator setup
sections.text:
The experimental set-up for measuring the temporal variations of the fluid temperature and the rate of vapor generation is shown in Fig. 2. The main components are a solar simulator with a 1600- watt xenon lamp (with the radiation temperature of 6000 K and an excellent spectral coverage in the ultra violet and visible bands with emission lines in the infrared that can be filtered to closely match the sun spectrum), a glass vessel containing the nanofluid
(a beaker with the diameter of 38 mm and the height of 70 mm), temperature sensors, a digital weighing balance (Kernel with the accuracy of 0.0001 g, Germany), CMP3 secondary standard pyranometer (obtained from Kipp & Zonen Co. with a precision of 1Wm 2 the wavelength range of 200–2800 nm), and a data accusation system (obtained from VIRA Equipment Unique Engineering Co.). To measure the temperature variations of the fluid at different heights, three thermometers were mounted at 50, 30 and 10 mm from the bottom of the vessel. Special care was taken to ensure that temperature sensors were not directly exposed to the incident light during the test; therefore, the exposed side of all sensors is protected by a silicone adhesive. The sensors were DS18B20 calibrated at various temperatures (100, 80, 50, 40, 30, 20, 10, 5 C). The calculated uncertainty associated with the temperature readings owing to the accuracy and equipment repeatability are 0.0.1 C and0.4 C, respectively, which brings the total uncertainty of 0.400 C.
A glass beaker filled with 60 ml nanofluid or water is used in the tests. To provide the required irradiation, the distance between the
lamp and the beaker is adjusted considering the Fresnel lens type. The magnitude of irradiation is measured by a pyranometer and recorded by the data accusation system. The weight of remained fluid in the beaker as a measure of the evaporation rate is recorded. Moreover, the fluid temperature at three different heights, and the environment temperature were documented.

sections.heading: 4. Results and discussions
sections.text:
The study of optical characteristics of fluids such as light absorption is vital when the solar heating and evaporation are concerned. To measure the ability of light absorption in the visible light spectrum a spectrophotometric device (Agilent 8453 Model) was used with the optical path-length 10 mm. In Fig. 3a–d the absorption spectra of different nanofluid samples in the wavelength interval of 300–800 nm, covering the visible wavelength are presented for three nanoparticle mass fractions of 0.001%, 0.002%, and 0.004%. The considered wavelength interval is due to the limitations of our measuring device. Otherwise, the solar spectrum covers a much wider wavelength domain.
As presented in Fig. 3e, it can be observed that by loading any type of nanoparticles even at a relatively low mass fraction of 0.001% the light absorption of pure water considerably increases in the visible spectrum. Visible light absorption of water is almost negligible at smaller wavelengths, which is increased considerably by adding nanoparticles. For all examined carbon nanoparticles, light absorption is more pronounced at larger nanoparticles concentrations and lower end of the visible light spectrum.
The light absorption performance of the nonmetallic nanoparticles is also related to their bandgap parameter. It is well established that the absorption of the nanoparticles increases as their bandgap decreases. In Fig. 3f the bandgap of all considered nanoparticles is presented. Clearly, MWCNT with the smallest bandgap of 2.65 eV, as compared to the GO with the largest bandgap of 4.7 eV, is expected to be more efficient in solar energy absorption. The corresponding band gap for the nanofluid containing GNP and SWCNT are about 3.29, 3.8 eV, respectively. As expected, the order of the considered nanoparticles based on their effectiveness in solar energy absorption according to their bandgap measure is consistent with their order according to their absorption spectra.
Although, 55% of solar energy lies in the visible spectra region, however, still an assessment of their actual performance in solar steam generation that covers the complete solar spectra is required.

sections.heading: 4.1. Temperature rising and evaporation rates
sections.text:
To assess the solar evaporation capabilities of the considered nanofluids, a number of tests were conducted at the irradiations of 3.5 kWm 2 (or 3.5 Suns) using the solar simulator. Fig. 4a displays the time variations of the uppermost fluid temperature rise related to the T1 sensor for the pure water along with the considered nanofluids with the initial mass concentration of 0.004%. The temperature rise is defined as the difference between the fluid real time temperature at a given height and the fluid temperature
at the starting point of the test. As it can be realized, after 30 min of light exposure, the largest temperature rising related to the T1 sensor is about 29.7 C, 27.94 C, 25.81 C, and 23.5 C, respectively, for nanofluid containing MWCNT, GNP, SWCNT and GO nanoparticles, as compared to the pure water temperature rise which is just about 17.5 C.
Fig. 4b presents the time variations of the evaporated mass for all examined nanofluids samples. Considering Fig. 4b, the highest evaporated mass is about 1.23 kg/m2 which is obtained for MWCNT nanofluid (3.11 times more than that of water) while GO-based nanofluid produces just 0.63 kg/m2 vapor (lowest performance among nanofluids). These findings are consistent with the bandgap data and the absorption spectra discussed earlier, and also with the fluid temperature rise close to the fluid surface.
To gain an insight into how the fluid temperature varies with time at different fluid elevations, Fig. 4c presents the temperature rising at different depths of MWCNT nanofluid with the initial mass concentration of 0.004%. The temperature sensors placed at 50, 30 and 10 mm from the bottom of the beaker are, respectively, denoted by T3, T2, and T1, while Tamb represents the ambient tem-
perature. Similar results for other considered nanofluids are given in Appendix A. As expected, the absorbed light is stronger at the upper layers of the fluid, which is in accordance with the BeerLambert law (Wang et al., 2017c; Swinehar, 1962). Beer-Lambert law declares that a significant portion of the light passing via a colloid is absorbed by the upper exposed layers.
4.2. The effects of irradiation
Tests were conducted at different irradiations of 1.5, 2.5, and 3.5 Suns for water and nanofluids containing MWCNT, GNP, SWCNT and GO nanoparticles for a given mass concentration of 0.004 wt%. Fig. 5 presents the rise of nanofluids temperature and evaporation rates after 30 min. The results reveal that both fluid temperature rising and evaporation rate increase with an increase in irradiation. However, it is clear that with the increase of irradiation a larger proportion of the absorbed energy is used for heating the fluid because of the deeper penetration of the light into the fluid; this consequently increases the sensible heating efficiency, as will be discussed later.

sections.heading: 4.3. The effects of nanoparticle concentration
sections.text:
The effects of nanoparticle concentration on the fluid temperature rising and steam generation have been examined by considering the sensible heating and evaporation efficiencies for all types of nanofluids. The fraction of the absorbed incident light energy that is used for heating the fluid is demonstrated by sensible heat efficiency, while the portion used for the vapor generation determines the evaporation efficiency. Obviously, the rest of input energy, which is transferred to the environment, reads as loss efficiency. Fig. 6 illustrates the evaporation, sensible heating and loss efficiencies of the various nanofluids at different nanoparticle concentrations as compared to that of water exposed to the light concentration of 3.5 Suns. For a specific type of nanoparticles, particle loading enhances both of evaporation and sensible heating efficiencies which can be explained by the Beer’s law as described in Appendix A. The highest total efficiency, which includes sensible heating and evaporation efficiencies, is obtained for MWCNTs (w = 0.004%) with 94%, while the corresponding values for the nanofluids containing SWCNTs, GNP, GO nanoparticles and the case of pure water are about 91%, 90%, 81%, and 54%, respectively.
Based on the sensible heating efficiency of samples, one can find the suitable carbon nanostructure for the solar energy storage applications. According to Fig. 6 graphene oxide shows the most considerable sensible heating efficiency at a mass concentration of 0.004%. To assess the performance of nanofluids with respect to the sensible heating capacity, the increase of bulk temperature of nanofluids samples with a mass fraction of 0.004% has been monitored for 30 min under irradiation of 3.5 Suns, while for the next 30 min the bulk fluid temperature variations were recorded with the light off condition as presented in Fig. 7. Since the thermal conductivity of nanofluid plays an important role in fluid temperature variations, it has been measured for all nanofluids at nanoparticle mass concentration of 0.004% and temperature of
35 C as listed in Table 1. The table also includes the total bulk temperature drops during the light off period for all nanofluids and water.
Graphene oxide-based nanofluid with the highest thermal conductivity provides the biggest temperature rise as much as 21.5 C. MWCNT nanofluid with the largest evaporation efficiency among the samples shows the lowest bulk fluid temperature rise of 18.2 C, which is accompanied by the 10.4 C temperature drop during the light off period. It must be emphasized that the surface temperature of MWCNT nanofluid is about 6 C higher than that of the GO nanofluid at the end of light on period.

sections.heading: 5. Comparative study
sections.text:
Normally, the objective of using carbon-based nanoparticles in solar vapor generation is the localization of both light absorption and photothermal energy conversion in the suspension. In this section, a comparative study between the evaporation efficiency of examined nanofluids and other types of nanofluids considered in the literature is performed as shown in Fig. 8. The information of each reference cited in Fig. 8 has been given in Table 1s in the appendix. Considering Fig. 8 and Table 1s, it is evident that utilizing composite nanoparticles such as Fe3O4/RGO (Wang et al., 2016b), Au/GO (Fu et al., 2017), and Fe3O4/CNT (Shi et al., 2017) can enhance the evaporation efficiency remarkably. However, for selecting the suitable nanoparticles for solar steam generation, not only evaporation efficiency, but other factors such as production cost of nanoparticles should be considered. For example, as stated by Zeiny et al. (2018), production of vapor by gold nanoparticles could be up to 300 times more expensive than vapor production by carbon nanotubes. Various parameters such as mass fraction, morphology, thermal conductivity, and optical properties of nanoparticles as well as irradiation determine the evaporation efficiency of nanofluids. In addition, the preparation method of
nanofluids can affect the evaporation efficiency. For example, sonication time or adding surfactant to nanofluid may affect the nanofluid evaporation efficiency.

sections.heading: 6. Quality of produced water
sections.text:
When nanoparticles are applied to enhance the steam generation rate and consequently pure water production, a concern is the quality of condensed water. Therefore, it is important to test the quality of produced water to be sure it is suitable for drinking. As will be discussed, the produced water with this approach meets the required drinking water standards without any extra efforts, while other methods such as purification (Negishi et al., 2019) and hydrophilic nanofiltration (NF) and reverse osmosis (RO)
membranes (Alzahrani et al., 2013) commonly needs additional treatments, which are costly (Oka et al., 2017; Nielsen et al., 2018).
Here, the quality of the condensed water obtained from seawater was tested and the results indicated that the type of nanoparticles do not affect the condensation process and overall quality of water. Fig. 9 presents a comparison between the values of five ions including Na+, Mg2+, K+, Ca2+, B3+ in both seawater sample and the produced water where MWCNTs based nanofluid was used. As seen, the values of ions in seawater is higher than allowable limits, while for condensed water the values of these ions lie in allowable limits so that the healthy level of produced water is acceptable. It should be noted that the allowable limits for ions in drinking water were determined according to the World Health Organization (WHO) standards (World Health Organization, 2011; World Health Organization chronicle, 2011). As mentioned, the
results of Fig. 9 are for MWCNTs; similar results were obtained for other types of nanofluids so they are not presented here.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text:
The performance of carbon nanoparticles in solar vapor generation was examined experimentally, using a solar simulator set-up. The considered nanoparticles were SWCNT, MWCNT, GNP, and GO
at various nanoparticle mass fractions of 0.001%, 0.002%, and 0.004% and irradiations of 1.5, 2.3, 3.5 Suns. The effects of nanoparticle mass fraction and irradiation on the light absorbed, temperature rise, evaporated mass were investigated in details. The results establish a reasonable potential for application of carbon nanoparticles in vapor production and direct solar energy absorption. Nanofluids containing MWCNT nanoparticles showed superior performance in solar energy absorption with the total efficiency of 94% at a mass concentration of 0.004% and under 3.5 Suns

As far as the sensible heat is concerned, graphene oxide shows the largest sensible heating efficiency at the mass concentration of 0.004% with the maximum fluid bulk temperature rise of 20.5 C, which is 40% higher than that of water. It was also found that with increasing the light concentration from 1.5 to 3.5 Suns, the evaporated mass enhances from 0.64 kg/m2 to 1.22 kg/m2 for MWCNT nanofluid at a mass fraction of 0.004% whereas the evaporation efficiency reduces from 0.54 to 0.44. For example, gold (Neumann et al., 2013; Jin et al., 2016) and silver (Li et al., 2017) nanoparticles when exposed to the solar radiation can generate a dramatic heat via a surface plasmonic effect, increasing their local temperature. Jin et al. (2016), Amjad et al. (2017) and Wang et al. (2017b) studied the performance of Au nanoparticles on solar steam generation. The total efficiency was found to be 81% at solar irradiation of 220 Suns (Jin et al., 2016), 80.3% at 280 Suns (Amjad et al., 2017), and 65% at 10 Suns (Wang et al., 2017b). It should be mentioned that metallic nanomaterials mainly react to a partial range of the solar spectrum, while the performance of a large number of the light-absorbing organic materials decay with aging. Therefore, it is a challenge to find a photothermal converter with high efficiency and stability properties. Evidently, the low efficiency of direct solar energy conversion systems is still one of the main obstacles in their commercialization (Wang et al., 2017c, 2017a). Carbon nanostructures in the solar-driven steam generation have recently attracted attention due to their appropriate band gap for photothermal solar energy conversion and also the important applications of the low-cost generated steam. Ni et al. (2015) reported steam generation efficiency of 69% at the solar intensity of 10 Suns via carbon black, graphene and graphitized carbon black dispersed in water with the mass concentration of 0.5%. Wang et al. (2016a) investigated the performance of CNT in solar vapor generation.
